title: Can you solve the false positive riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of finding unobtainium in the mine?
What is the probability of a false positive reading from the unobtainium detector?
Why is it a bad idea to trust the unobtainium detector's reading?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the detector is not reliable.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the detector is not accurate.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the probability of a false positive is higher than the probability of finding unobtainium.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the detector is not designed to detect unobtainium.

multiple-choice.question: What is the base rate fallacy?

options.label: A
options.text: The tendency to focus on specific information over general information.

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to ignore the probability of a false positive.

options.label: C
options.text: The tendency to overestimate the accuracy of a detector.

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency to underestimate the rarity of a mineral.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between unconditional and conditional probability?

options.label: A
options.text: Unconditional probability is the probability of an event happening, while conditional probability is the probability of an event happening given that another event has occurred.

options.label: B
options.text: Unconditional probability is the probability of an event happening given that another event has occurred, while conditional probability is the probability of an event happening.

options.label: C
options.text: Unconditional probability is the probability of an event happening, while conditional probability is the probability of an event not happening.

options.label: D
options.text: Unconditional probability is the probability of an event not happening, while conditional probability is the probability of an event happening.

title: What causes constipation? - Heba Shaheed

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of constipation?

options.label: A
options.text: The food you eat is too spicy.

options.label: B
options.text: The stool moves excessively slowly through the intestines.

options.label: C
options.text: The pelvic floor muscles are too weak.

options.label: A
options.text: To contract the external anal sphincter.

options.label: B
options.text: To form a sling-like formation around the rectum called the anorectal angle.

options.label: C
options.text: To relax the internal anal sphincter.

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb water from the stool.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Bristol Stool Chart used for?

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the different types of stool.

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended daily water intake to help prevent constipation?

options.label: A
options.text: Sitting on the toilet seat with your back straight.

options.label: B
options.text: Standing up with your feet shoulder-width apart.

options.label: C
options.text: Squatting with your buttocks firmly on the toilet seat and your feet elevated on a stool.

options.label: D
options.text: Lying down on the floor with your legs straight up.

title: The impostor syndrome

multiple-choice.question: What is the root core of the impostor syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: A hugely helpful picture of what other people are really like.

options.label: B
options.text: A hugely unhelpful picture of what other people are really like.

options.label: C
options.text: A picture of what we want to be like.

options.label: D
options.text: A picture of what we don't want to be like.

options.label: A
options.text: The leap that we are uniquely flawed.

options.label: B
options.text: The leap that others' minds must work in basically much the same way as ours do.

options.label: C
options.text: The leap that we are better than others.

options.label: D
options.text: The leap that we are worse than others.

options.label: C
options.text: Self-doubt and feelings of inadequacy, sometimes bumping into doors and having weird, lustful thoughts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of making a leap of faith around what other people are really like?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more confident and less anxious.

options.label: B
options.text: We become more isolated and less connected to others.

options.label: C
options.text: We humanize the world and understand that others are, in spite of surface evidence, very much like us.

options.label: D
options.text: We become more critical and less empathetic towards others.

title: Which is stronger: Glue or tape? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the oldest glue in the world?

options.label: B
options.text: A cave near the Dead Sea

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between adhesive bonds and cohesive bonds in glues?

options.label: A
options.text: Adhesive bonds occur between the glue's molecules and the surface it's sticking to, while cohesive bonds happen between the glue's molecules.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Adhesive bonds occur between the surface's molecules and the air, while cohesive bonds happen between the glue's molecules.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why tape is able to form weaker, reversible bonds with surfaces?

options.text: Because it has a stronger adhesive than glue.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a weaker adhesive than glue.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it forms Van der Waals forces with the surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a higher melting point than glue.

title: How do touchscreens work?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main differences between old-school touchscreens and modern touchscreens?

options.label: C
options.text: Old-school touchscreens are less responsive to touch patterns.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the spacers in a resistive touchscreen?

options.label: B
options.text: To insulate the layers from each other.

options.label: C
options.text: To apply a voltage to the screen.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a conductive object, such as a finger, touches a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: The electrostatic field is disrupted, and the processor can detect the touch.

options.label: B
options.text: The electrostatic field is not affected, and the processor cannot detect the touch.

options.label: C
options.text: The electrostatic field is strengthened, and the processor can detect the touch more accurately.

options.label: D
options.text: The electrostatic field is weakened, and the processor cannot detect the touch.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of capacitive touchscreens over resistive touchscreens?

options.label: C
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens are more accurate and can process multiple touches at a time.

options.label: D
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens are less responsive to touch patterns.

multiple-choice.question: Why do capacitive touchscreens not work with gloves on?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cloth in the gloves is conductive.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the cloth in the gloves is not conductive.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the processor in the device is not designed to work with gloves.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the screen is not designed to work with gloves.

title: How architecture can create dignity for all

multiple-choice.question: What was the author's experience like in the hospital room where his daughter was born?

options.label: B
options.text: It was a comfortable and dignified experience.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a windowless room with fluorescent lights, beige walls, and beeping machines.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a room with a view of the outside world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main argument about the field of architecture?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a highly theoretical and elitist profession.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a male-dominated profession that prioritizes aesthetics over social impact.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is a field that is disconnected from the people most directly impacted by its work.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a field that is solely focused on designing buildings for the wealthy.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is a representation of the lack of dignity in design.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a sense of security and dignity to its residents.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's proposal for changing the field of architecture?

options.label: A
options.text: That designers should focus solely on creating beautiful buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: That designers should prioritize the needs of the wealthy and powerful.

options.label: C
options.text: That designers should dedicate their practices to the public good.

options.label: D
options.text: That designers should only work on projects that are profitable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Winston Churchill's quote "We shape our buildings, and afterward, they shape us"?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the importance of building beautiful and functional buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: It emphasizes the impact of buildings on our mental and emotional well-being.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that buildings can shape our values and attitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: It implies that buildings are mere physical structures with no significance.

title: Why can't you divide by zero?

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we divide by zero?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would make the answer too big.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would make the answer too small.

options.label: C
options.text: Because zero has no multiplicative inverse.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would make the answer equal to infinity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the multiplicative inverse of a number?

options.label: A
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives a result greater than 1.

options.label: B
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives a result equal to 1.

options.label: C
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives a result less than 1.

options.label: D
options.text: A number that, when multiplied by the original number, gives a result equal to 0.

multiple-choice.question: What happens if we try to define infinity as the multiplicative inverse of zero?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a new mathematical world of complex numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to a contradiction, where 1 equals 2.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a new way of dividing by zero using the Riemann sphere.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to a new way of multiplying numbers.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not useful to have infinity equal to zero?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would make calculations easier.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would make calculations harder.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would make the answer equal to 1.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would make the answer equal to 0.

multiple-choice.question: What is the transcript mentions as a way to divide by zero using a different method?

options.label: D
options.text: Religions no longer terrify us into staying, society doesn't care, and psychologists now routinely tell us that children would prefer a broken family to an unhappy one

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the questions that can be asked to help a person decide whether to stay or leave their relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: How much money do we have in savings?

options.label: B
options.text: How much of our unhappiness can be tightly attributed to this particular partner?

options.label: C
options.text: How many people are we friends with on social media?

options.label: D
options.text: How many times have we argued this week?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the steps that can be taken to help a person decide whether to stay or leave their relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to have another conversation with your partner in which you accuse them of mendacity

options.label: B
options.text: Reflect on how you'd really feel as a child

options.label: C
options.text: Compare the current setup with the reality of having two tiny bedrooms, two new step-parents, and possibly a few more new half-siblings

options.label: D
options.text: Ask yourself if you're ready to face the risk of achieving no more than exchanging a familiar kind of unhappiness for a new and more complex variety of unhappiness

title: The difference between the United Kingdom, Great Britain and England explained

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the United Kingdom's four co-equal and sovereign nations?

options.label: C
options.text: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is NOT a country within the United Kingdom?
What is the term for the geographical area that includes England, Scotland, and Wales?
What is the term for the former colonies that gained independence through diplomacy and continue to recognize the authority of the Crown?
What is the term for the tiny city on the southern coast of Spain that is a British Overseas Territory?

title: A simple way to tell insects apart - Anika Hazra

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of studying the mouthparts of insects?

options.label: B
options.text: To identify the species and order of an insect

options.label: C
options.text: To learn about their defense mechanisms

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following mouthparts is the most primitive?
What is the function of the pseudotracheae in the sponging mouthpart?

options.label: B
options.text: To pierce plant or animal tissue

options.label: C
options.text: To secrete enzyme-filled saliva and soak up fluids

multiple-choice.question: Which order of insects uses the siphoning mouthpart?
What is a unique characteristic of the chewing-lapping mouthpart?

options.label: A
options.text: The mandibles are used for eating

options.label: B
options.text: The proboscis is used for pollen-collecting

options.label: C
options.text: The tongue-like structure is used for lapping up nectar

options.label: D
options.text: The mouthpart is only found in adult insects

title: French and English gardens

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the famous French garden designed by André le Nôtre in the late 1650s?
What is the main difference between the French and English gardening traditions?

options.label: A
options.text: The French tradition uses more flowers, while the English tradition uses more trees.

options.label: B
options.text: The French tradition flattens the natural landscape, while the English tradition works with natural features.

options.label: C
options.text: The French tradition is more formal, while the English tradition is more casual.

options.label: D
options.text: The French tradition is more expensive, while the English tradition is more affordable.

multiple-choice.question: Who is the central figure in the English gardening tradition?
What is the name of the English garden that borrows from both the French and English traditions?
What is the ideal approach to life, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A purely rational and willful approach, like the French tradition.

options.label: B
options.text: A purely accepting and accommodating approach, like the English tradition.

options.label: C
options.text: An integration of both rational willpower and acceptance of nature.

options.label: D
options.text: A complete rejection of both traditions.

title: A day in the life of a Roman soldier - Robert Garland

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the emperor who is currently ruling the Roman Empire?
What is the distance that Servius's legion, along with three others, has undertaken as part of their "great march"?
What is the name of the leader who prevented a wholesale mutiny among some legions in the area last year?
What is the name of the forest where six years ago, Germanic tribes under their chieftain Arminius ambushed and destroyed three legions?
How many years of service does Servius have left before he can retire and marry his intended wife?
